name: Brett Tanonaka
description: Portfolio to present my work as a full stack engineer and soon to feature my work as a video producer.

projects.alt: GIF showing that hovering over a project will underline it

background.alt: GIF showing how the background gradient follows the mouse's position

projectDetails.alt: GIF clicking on a project that takes you to the project's details

contact.alt: GIF showing a modal indicating a message was sent successfully

goal.part1: When I was a video producer, I used Squarespace for my portfolio and while it is a powerful tool, there are limitations to template based website generators.

background.part1: I wanted the background to be able to interact with the mouse position and decided to do so with a gradient.
background.part2: This is accomplished by using a window event listener and saving the clientX and clientY position to their own states. The states are then used as the focal point in a radial gradient.

projectDetails.part1: Each project can be clicked on to take the user to a separate page that displays the project’s description, my roles, and the technology stack used. The details page also includes photos and gifs of the live application

contact.part1: The contact form is connected to a MongoDB database that stores the user’s name, email, and message. When a message is successfully submitted, a modal appears with a thank you note. An error appears when the message is not able to be sent.

name: Fitbook
description: Social media application to bring together fitness minded individuals. Create communities, host events, find gym buddies and promote a healthy lifestyle.

messages.alt: Message friend from profile friends tab

text.contribution: I created the individual community component and wrote seed functions to generate dummy data to use during development. As the UI Lead, I designed the application and used Figma’s prototype tool to simulate navigation prior to development.
text.community: The individual community page includes a banner, name, event carousel, and post feed. Users are able to join or leave the community and have their home feed filter posts from that community.

name: Mevify
description: An API for a client-facing e-commerce website.

k6.alt: Pre-optimization local test product id endpoint

text.database: Node.js is the server environment and PostgreSQL was selected as the database because it offers native functions to assemble data intensive queries directly from the database, such as json_build_object and json_agg.
text.schema: The schema was designed to match the structure of the CSV files with some primary keys being connected to other tables as foreign keys.

results.title: Results
results.takeaway: Creating proper queries and indexes has a significant impact on response speed. Once that has been optimized, I found it more impactful to shift my focus to horizontal scaling.

data.part1: An ETL process was performed on approximately five million rows of data from seven CSV files.
data.part2: Having a pre-existing front end, the data structure for each endpoint was defined so the queries needed to match that structure.

text.blurb: I created an API for a client-facing e-commerce website. All work was done independently and was reviewed by two peers.

queries.part1: The initial queries for the most intensive endpoint when running a single request using Postman, hovered between 7-8 seconds.
queries.part2: After using binary tree indexes on the primary and foreign keys in each table, latency decreased to 100ms per request on average for about 1000 requests per second. The initial tests were run on a local machine using K6.

deploy.part1: The server and database were then deployed on separate AWS: EC2 instances.
deploy.part2: After adding two additional servers and a load balancer using Nginx (each on their own EC2 instance), each server could handle about 800 requests per second with each request response time averaging around 60ms. Deployed testing was conducted on Loader.io.

snippets.part1: Approximately 440 requests per second; 79ms response time
snippets.part2: Testing with three servers and a load balancer; handling a combined 2400 r/s
snippets.part3: Testing 5,000 and 7,500 requests per second on five deployed AWS:EC2 instances

name: Wired Wardrobe
description: A single page item description page for an e-commerce brand.

name: LitterSort
description: Open source web application that uses AI to examine images of trash and tells you whether to recycle, compost, or put the item in the landfill. In collaboration with Open Source San Jose.

camera.alt: Uploaded photo before sending to AI

success.alt: More information for the plastic category

logo.alt: Logo of Littersort, a leaf sticking out of a bottole

camera.part1: Users are able to take a photo with their camera and submit it for analysis. The AI predicts what is in the image along with a confidence rating.
camera.part2: Since the AI is still being trained, the user can select a different category if they know the prediction is wrong.

blurb.part1: The LitterSort team consists of five people and I lead the design and development of the front end of the web application. All work is volunteer based and the project is organized through Open Source San Jose (part of the Code for America brigade).
blurb.part2: Recycling in California is handled at the district level and instructions for how an individual piece of trash should be disposed of can differ by city. A future goal of LitterSort is to provide granular information based on zip code.
blurb.part3: The application is optimized for mobile but it is accessible on tablets and desktops as well.

more.part1: Once the predicted or corrected category is confirmed, the user is provided general information on how to dispose of the item.
more.part2: A modal with additional information can be provided by clicking on the ‘Learn More’ button.

text.profile: Users have the option but are not required to create an account where they can track the number of times they uploaded an item belonging to each category.

leaderboard.part1: The leaderboard can sort and display the top 10 users for each category. The default category is total uploads.
leaderboard.part2: If a user is logged in, their current ranking and image count for the selected category is displayed above the leaderboard.
